repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: Add a test to try coercing Python objects (like `bytes` and typed-memoryviews) to and from `std::string_view`.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,6 +35,30 @@ def test_return_to_py():
     return return_to_py()
 
 
+def test_coercion_py(py_str):
+    """
+    >>> b_asdf_5 = b_asdf * 5
+    >>> test_coercion_py(b_asdf_5)
+    """
+    if not isinstance(py_str, bytes):
+        return
+
+    cdef string_view sv1 = py_str
+    assert len(py_str) == sv1.size()
+    assert <const char*>py_str == sv1.data()
+
+    cdef const char[:] mv1 = sv1
+    assert len(mv1) = sv1.size()

@@ -35,6 +35,30 @@ def test_return_to_py():
     return return_to_py()
 
 
+def test_coercion_py(py_str):
+    """
+    >>> b_asdf_5 = b_asdf * 5
+    >>> test_coercion_py(b_asdf_5)
+    """
+    if not isinstance(py_str, bytes):
+        return
+
+    cdef string_view sv1 = py_str
+    assert len(py_str) == sv1.size()
+    assert <const char*>py_str == sv1.data()
+
+    cdef const char[:] mv1 = sv1
+    assert len(mv1) == sv1.size()
+    if py_str:
+        assert &mv1[0] == sv1.data()
+
+    cdef const char[:] mv2 = py_str
+    cdef string_view sv2 = mv2
+    assert len(mv2) = sv2.size()

comment_data.body:
Looks like this case fails

Was hoping it would do something equivalent to

```cython
cdef const char[:] mv1 = <char[:sv1.length():1]><const char*>sv1.data()
```

However it looks like this doesn't work for `std::string` either. Plus this is a non-owning instance. So it makes sense why we might want to add more hoops to jump through for this case

+    assert <const char*>py_str == sv1.data()

+    cdef const char[:] mv1 = sv1

comment_data.body:
Looks like this doesn't work out of the box. FWIW `std::string` does

Maybe we can try typing it as `bytes`

```suggestion
    cdef string_view sv1 = <bytes>py_str
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,6 +35,25 @@ def test_return_to_py():
     return return_to_py()
 
 
+def test_coercion_py(py_str):
+    """
+    >>> b_asdf_5 = b_asdf * 5
+    >>> test_coercion_py(b_asdf_5)
+    """
+    if not isinstance(py_str, bytes):
+        return
+
+    cdef string_view sv1 = py_str

comment_data.body:
> `cdef const char[:] mv1 = <char[:sv1.length():1]><const char*>sv1.data()`

Shouldn't that be

```
cdef const char[:] mv1 = <const char[:sv1.length():1]><const char*>sv1.data()
```

?

I think it's reasonable to jump through hoops for this and strings because the memoryview can't own them

+    assert len(py_str) == sv1.size()
+    assert <const char*>py_str == sv1.data()
+
+    cdef const char[:] mv1 = sv1

comment_data.body:
Both seemed to work, but agree `const char` would be better

Excluding this case makes sense. Didn't quite follow the last bit

     return return_to_py()
 
 
+def test_coercion_py(py_str):

comment_data.body:
Looks like the last assignment breaks down on the C++ side

Wondering if we need to extend some existing Cython logic

This in particular stick out, but maybe there are other code paths worth looking at

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/bf59121ba5c9f79b4bbfeab05407c15e07e4cb15/Cython/Utility/CppConvert.pyx#L4-L35
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,6 +35,25 @@ def test_return_to_py():
     return return_to_py()
 
 
+def test_coercion_py(py_str):
+    """
+    >>> b_asdf_5 = b_asdf * 5
+    >>> test_coercion_py(b_asdf_5)
+    """
+    if not isinstance(py_str, bytes):
+        return
+
+    cdef string_view sv1 = <bytes>py_str
+    assert len(py_str) == sv1.size()
+    assert <const char*>py_str == sv1.data()
+
+    cdef const char[:] mv = py_str
+    cdef string_view sv2 = mv
